source:
# Outline:
# 1. build the dataframe, display possible correlation between variables
# 2. build a linear regression model with 2 variables: item_id and item_cnt_day,
#    and evaluate the prediction results
# 3. two ways to improve the model:
#    3.1. data cleaning by excluding extreme records,
#           - repeat the model validation
#    3.2. multiple linear regression model with 3 variables,
#           - estimate the correlation with 3D plot
#           - build the multiple linear regression model
#           - evaluation of model

source:
#!/usr/bin/env python3
# code for linear regression model taken from: https://towardsdatascience.com/a-beginners-guide-to-linear-regression-in-python-with-scikit-learn-83a8f7ae2b4f
# dateset taken from: https://www.kaggle.com/c/competitive-data-science-predict-future-sales/data

import pandas as pd  
import numpy as np  
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt  
import seaborn as seabornInstance 
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split 
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
from sklearn import metrics
%matplotlib inline

dataset = pd.read_csv('/Users/user/downloads/competitive-data-science-predict-future-sales/sales_train.csv')

dataset.head()
dataset.shape

source:
plt.figure(figsize=(15,10))
plt.title('distribution of item_cnt_day')  
plt.xlabel('item_cnt_day')  
plt.tight_layout()
seabornInstance.distplot(dataset['item_cnt_day'])
print("There are 3 possible features: shop_id, item_id, item_price. Each correlation can be estimated by 2D ploting.")
print("Dot plot is chosen because each sale record is independent. ")

dataset.plot(x='item_id', y='item_cnt_day', style='o')  
plt.title('item_id vs item_cnt_day')  
plt.xlabel('item_id')  
plt.ylabel('item_cnt_day')  

plt.show()

dataset.plot(x='shop_id', y='item_cnt_day', style='o')  
plt.title('shop_id vs item_cnt_day')  
plt.xlabel('shop_id')  
plt.ylabel('item_cnt_day')

plt.show()

dataset.plot(x='item_price', y='item_cnt_day', style='o')  
plt.title('item_price vs item_cnt_day')  
plt.xlabel('item_price')  
plt.ylabel('item_cnt_day')

plt.show()
print("Combine the 3 figures together.")

x1= dataset['item_id']
y1= dataset['item_cnt_day']
x2= dataset['shop_id']
y2= dataset['item_cnt_day']
x3= dataset['item_price']
y3= dataset['item_cnt_day']

fig, axes = plt.subplots(3, 1,figsize=(12, 10))

axes[0].plot(x1,y1,'o',color='black')
axes[1].plot(x2,y2,'o',color='blue')
axes[2].plot(x3,y3,'o')
fig.tight_layout()
plt.show()

print("The correlation between item_id and item_cnt_day is similar to that of shop_id and item_cnt_day.")
print("So the linear regression model between item_id and item_cnt_day will be used as an example.")
print("Before building the model, the range of the outcomes can be estimated.")
print("The distribution of item_cnt_day is mostly concentrated on 1, so it is safe to estimate the possible outcomes of item_cnt_day to be around 1.")

X = dataset['item_id'].values.reshape(-1,1)
y = dataset['item_cnt_day'].values.reshape(-1,1)

# split 80% of the data to the training set while 20% of the data to test set using below code.
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.2, random_state=0)

regressor = LinearRegression()  
regressor.fit(X_train, y_train) #training the algorithm

#To retrieve the intercept:
print(regressor.intercept_)
#For retrieving the slope:
print(regressor.coef_)

y_pred = regressor.predict(X_test)

df = pd.DataFrame({'Actual': y_test.flatten(), 'Predicted': y_pred.flatten()})
df

df1 = df.head(25)
df1.plot(kind='bar',figsize=(16,10))
plt.grid(which='major', linestyle='-', linewidth='0.5', color='green')
plt.grid(which='minor', linestyle=':', linewidth='0.5', color='black')
plt.show()

plt.scatter(X_test, y_test,  color='gray')
plt.plot(X_test, y_pred, color='red', linewidth=2)
plt.show()

outputs.name: stdout
text:
Mean Absolute Error: 0.44476663473817024
Mean Squared Error: 6.252071662775697
Root Mean Squared Error: 2.500414298226535

source:
print('Mean Absolute Error:', metrics.mean_absolute_error(y_test, y_pred))  
print('Mean Squared Error:', metrics.mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred))  
print('Root Mean Squared Error:', np.sqrt(metrics.mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred)))

print("Seen from the model validation above, this algorithm is not very accurate but can still make reasonably predictions.")
print("The predicted values of item_cnt_day has decimal points. However, in reality item_cnt_day can only be integers.")
print("There are some approaches to advance the model: ")
print("1. remove some extreme values from the training data. For example, excluding the recods that have a item_cnt_day value larger than 200 and only focusing on the most frequenct patterns.")
print("2. apply the multiple linear regression model to build a more complex model including all 3 features.")

#1. data cleaning: exclude records with item_cnt_day over 200

dataset2 = pd.read_csv('/Users/user/downloads/competitive-data-science-predict-future-sales/sales_train.csv')

rowindex = dataset2[dataset2['item_cnt_day']>200].index

dataset2.drop(rowindex, inplace=True)

X = dataset2['item_id'].values.reshape(-1,1)
y = dataset2['item_cnt_day'].values.reshape(-1,1)

# split 80% of the data to the training set while 20% of the data to test set using below code.
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.2, random_state=0)

regressor = LinearRegression()  
regressor.fit(X_train, y_train) #training the algorithm

#To retrieve the intercept:
print(regressor.intercept_)
#For retrieving the slope:
print(regressor.coef_)

y_pred = regressor.predict(X_test)

df2 = pd.DataFrame({'Actual': y_test.flatten(), 'Predicted': y_pred.flatten()})
df2

df1 = df.head(25)
df1.plot(kind='bar',figsize=(16,10))
plt.grid(which='major', linestyle='-', linewidth='0.5', color='green')
plt.grid(which='minor', linestyle=':', linewidth='0.5', color='black')
plt.show()

plt.scatter(X_test, y_test,  color='gray')
plt.plot(X_test, y_pred, color='red', linewidth=2)
plt.show()

source:
print('Mean Absolute Error:', metrics.mean_absolute_error(y_test, y_pred))  
print('Mean Squared Error:', metrics.mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred))  
print('Root Mean Squared Error:', np.sqrt(metrics.mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred)))
print("Comapred with the values of the frist model, the accuracy is improved.")

#2. multiple linear regression model

print("For the multiple linear regression model, analyzing 2 variables at a time, e.g. item_id and item_cnt_day.")
print("Use the 3D plot to estimate the correlation.")

# print("We can use the 3D plot to estimate the correlation.")

from mpl_toolkits.mplot3d import Axes3D

fig = plt.figure()
axes = fig.add_subplot(1, 1, 1, projection='3d')
#line = axes.scatter(dataset['item_id'], dataset['item_price'], dataset['item_cnt_day'])

X = dataset['item_id']
Y = dataset['item_price']
Z = dataset['item_cnt_day']

axes.scatter(X, Y, Z, c='b', marker = 'o')

axes.set_xlabel('item_id')
axes.set_ylabel('item_price')
axes.set_zlabel('item_cnt_day')

plt.show()

source:
X = dataset[['item_id', 'item_price']].values
y = dataset['item_cnt_day'].values

X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.2, random_state=0)

regressor = LinearRegression()  
regressor.fit(X_train, y_train)

coeff_df = pd.DataFrame(regressor.coef_,['item_id','item_price'], columns=['Coefficient'])  
coeff_df

y_pred = regressor.predict(X_test)

df = pd.DataFrame({'Actual': y_test, 'Predicted': y_pred})
df1 = df.head(25)

df1.plot(kind='bar',figsize=(10,8))
plt.grid(which='major', linestyle='-', linewidth='0.5', color='green')
plt.grid(which='minor', linestyle=':', linewidth='0.5', color='black')
plt.show()

source:
print('Mean Absolute Error:', metrics.mean_absolute_error(y_test, y_pred))  
print('Mean Squared Error:', metrics.mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred))  
print('Root Mean Squared Error:', np.sqrt(metrics.mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred)))
print("The accuracy doesn't change too much compared with the first model.")
print("So excluding some records is more efficient in improving the accuracy.")
